An Entangled web of emotions and details that will blow your mind...
I'm sure you've heard of Clannad After Story...
I'm sure you've heard about its reputation as an Emotional series...
I'm sure you've heard about the sheer popularity of the Clannad series...
And for all of this, there are a multitude of reasons... 
In a nutshell, After Story brings about a revolutionary, mind blowing level of depth, emotion, immersion, to an extent that is indescribable by words - though i will try my best. After Story is a CRITICAL watch for viewers of the original series, and it is the powerhouse of a season that MAKES Clannad oneof THE most reputable anime of all time.


As a standalone, neither of these seasons would hold anywhere near the amount of sway that Clannad as a series, as a brand - has on the anime community. Linking this Key anime series into one beautiful story creates something magical... So what exactly?


After Story for me came across as one of the most well thought out shows that I've seen in absolutely every aspect. 

Its execution is delicate and attentive throughout, and this immaculate attention to detail allows the show to make some of the most far fetched, obscure links imaginable that will not only have you crawling around for explanations, but make you feel a completely unique sense of sentimentality.


Moving on to its bolder techniques... I speculate that in terms of "AS", the first season is merely a setup to it - by taking the time to run the viewers through each character in great depth (and pretty equally) in the first season, AS begins with an immediate attachment to the viewer, and uses this emotional fragility to make heavy-hitting events.


AS is manipulative in the way it uses a technique i'm going to refer to as "The Wall" - It can build up the viewers' attachment and feelings to the characters and premise in one way, and then do something completely left field to shatter it: therefore leaving huge impact craters, and coming across as such a moving show.


Obviously, no production can be proved to make a good show, but the closest measurement conceivable would be that of the impact that it has on the viewer, and if you've read just above, you might have guessed that Clannad is for these reasons (in my opinion) a masterpiece.


This relentless combination of attachment, impact and meaningful, sentimental values and details (that are sometimes left deliberately unclear for subconscious impact) truly spark thoughts in the viewer, allowing them to be engulfed by the show's ethos, and therefore rendering Clannad to be not only a legendary anime, but an outlook on life.


It may surprise readers, but After story is not only a omnipotent conveyor of vivid emotions, and immersive emotional friction, but in terms of presentation: that too is on par with the same goals - of taking the viewer on the most meaningful, powerful roller-coaster journey conceivable.


In terms of ART, it fluctuates at times between different styles of drawing and vibrancy levels to accommodate the scene. It's generally very colourful and detailed , and so there's nothing that could have made it more effective...


The SOUND of Clannad as a whole (as it doesn't change much) is one of the best examples of sentimentality, and as you would (as a viewer) come to see, Clannad is able to imbue some formidable power into a small range of songs (primarily one consisting of little marshmallow-like people with eyes ;) ) These songs are continuously embedded at certain points as additional emotion-inducing devices.

In layman's terms: very fitting...


The CHARACTER development of AF is good, though heavily oriented towards Nagisa and Tomoyo (as the main characters) - while the rest remain themselves. A small selection of characters are added, but while Character Development was the strong suit of the original season, AF is much more event-based, and so this isn't its specialty.


ENJOYMENT?!

After Story sent me on THE most powerful emotional journey that an anime has ever taken me on before, and so while "enjoy" is by no means the right word here, but in a sense that i'm glad i watched it, i definitely enjoyed both seasons.


Overall, due to its sheer power and mind-boggling vividness, i give AF a 10; as i will always remember it for being a masterpiece - Though, i am aware that this delicate approach to anime doesn't appeal to everyone.

10/10, no doubt about it.
Generalities and Formalities.
Clannad: After story, is commonly referred to as one of the greatest animes to be ever written and created. It's up at the top with Steins;Gate and FMA, and all for a good reason. But before I get into these reasons, I have to point out the fact that Clannad: AS is the only Slice of Life anime to be in the top 5, and this is an impressive feat that gets overlooked. In a society of Anime dominated with the overwhelming fanbase of Shounen anime (action, fighting etc...), a Slice of Life anime able to break through thatcraze and emerge at the top. Personally, it is my number one anime out of all the animes I have watched. The reasons I will reach now.


Story. 10/10

Key, the writers of Angel Beats!, Little Busters (Refrain), Kanon, Clannad, and Air are known for their genius in writing amazing stories. They have become so famous to the point where Key has it's own anime genre (fan addressed) called "Key Anime" which refers to these slice of life animes which have a mind blowing, or completely heartbreaking/joyous ending. 

Now, getting to Clannad: AS. The story takes place after the original Clannad Television series, but instead follows mainly about life after highschool. The other factor which makes this show even more enjoyable and touching is the fact that the story and characters are so real. After Story does what Clannad (Original) could not do, and that is wrap up things and answer questions.

Of course I cannot say too much or it would ruin the story, but the first season's setup led perfectly into this second season, which developed the story into something truly beautiful, and will treasure in their hearts. I shit you not, I changed how I looked at life because of this anime.


Art. 10/10


Character Art:

Obviously not the most beautiful characters out there in the Anime Industry, whether it comes to OPPAI!!! (Highschool DxD) or design (Nagi no Asukara), but the art style to Key animes are very unique. After Story is no different. The characters are perfect for the story, and could not imagine it with any other art for the characters. The eyes especially display the sadness and happiness of a character extremely effeciently!


Scenery:

This anime was made quite a long time ago (2008-9). That was 5-6 years ago, yet, the artwork was consistently fantastic for the scenery. I will quickly and spoiler free mention examples. The snow, grass fields, everything to that sort, all were amazing. even surpassing some of the animes we have to this date.


Sound: 10/10

The music, was perfect for every situation. To this day, whenever I watch the opening for this show, I get chills and a wave of reminescence hits me like a hammer. Every single character has their own theme song, which plays continuously and fits them amazingly. The OST for the situations that the anime plays through also fit amazingly, and I am not exaggerating when I say that the music becomes a part of the story telling. Now, to the sound effects. These are standard, and for a bigger company like Key is unexpected, and of course, they do not mess it up. Every sound effect from baseball noises to eating, to plates, rain, cicadas, walking, are all great. The voice acting? Amazing. They used famous actors from all over the industry. We have people from one piece, fairy tail, highschool dxd, you get it, basically the best out there.


Characters. 10/10

In an anime based around story telling, what's a good story without a good set of characters? The characters are all very different, and yet they work very well together as a group. briefly, I will go over the characters and their characteristics.

Okazaki Tomoya - A delinquent, yet a very caring guy in the inside. He likes to take care of other people. He is very responsible, and much more mature than he lets on to be. He usually takes other people's problems into his own hands to help them as much as he can.

Furukawa Nagisa - A softspoken, shy girl. She opens more once she met Tomoya on the day of the opening ceremony, and becomes great friends with him. She quickly makes many friends with the help of Tomoya. She is naturally weak, as she was born with a frail body, yet she tries everything with everything she has. She also has a tendency to cry easily, and is very caring for others.

Sunohara Youhei - Delinquent, met Tomoya through a mutual trouble making incident. He is loud, obnoxious, and has trouble getting girls. However, he, like Tomoya, is secretly very caring. He is often referred to as a clown and a jokester, because he is not as mature as Tomoya is.

Allow me, before beginning, to quickly summarise my opinion of Clannad's first season, as I don't particularly fancy writing an entire review about it. Clannad season 1 was incredibly effective at delivering some serious emotional impact, but was arguably very melodramatic. Now that it's occurred to me, I can't escape the feeling that the first season was almost entirely filler, existing solely to skim over the VN arcs of the other characters without contributing anything particularly significant to the story, nor delivering any particular message. Ultimately, the directors could've taken several scenes in series 1 and tacked them onto the beginning of After Story, andpotentially produced a show that was of equal or better quality. I almost didn't watch After Story at all.


And, to be honest, my initial reaction was to drop it after only one episode, before picking it up again some weeks later. After Story begins with much of the same thing, resolving the arcs that were left untouched by season 1; those of the Sunohara siblings, Misae and Yukine. While this is my personal opinion, the first 2 arcs in particular didn't even possess much impact. I didn't cry at all. The third arc is when Clannad After Story begins to show its true colours, and while it is undeniably more of the same thing, the maturity of After Story begins to show at last, and I finally found myself crying after an underwhelming beginning. After that, it ditches the arc structure in favour of (finally) developing the primary characters of Tomoya and Nagisa, thus reaching its thematic crux.


You see, the latter half of After Story is when Clannad finally reveals the true reason for its existence. It discusses some mature themes: gang violence, drug abuse, depression and, at its core, family. In some ways, the characters of Tomoya and Nagisa mature with the series. Far from simply being moving, After Story becomes powerful. It has meaning. We finally begin to witness ideas that are relevant in some way, perhaps, to our own lives. The melodrama remains, but only serves to accentuate the ideas rather than failing to serve any purpose at all. And there are elements of the series that will leave you genuinely shaken, in particular two incredibly heart-wrenching scenes that reduced me to a flood of uncontrollable tears. Me, who is so cold that if you licked me your tongue would get stuck to my skin. God, that metaphor sounded so much better in my head.


That all aside, the ending is bloody awful. After one of those aforementioned heartbreakers, the final episode does some pretty strange stuff. And I personally choose to believe it never happened. I elect to believe that Clannad After Story's most heartbreaking scene is also its ending. But I can't escape that fact that that episode exists, and ruined an otherwise perfect second half.

Also, and I hate to say it, but I now despise Fuko. She annoys me too much for me to return to my previous adoration for her in season 1.


Guh, I hate using such emotive terminology when reviewing a series, but it's so difficult not to with Clannad. From a more objective standpoint, After Story's execution also improves drastically in the second half. The art remains about the same, with the only changes being representative of the physical growth of the characters. And the opening sequence is absolutely stunning!


So yeah, After Story is deceptively samey at first, but absolutely beautiful if you're willing to endure the initial arcs. A vast improvement on an average series, and arguably Key's greatest achievement. Even if you didn't particularly like season 1, watch season 2. You won't be disappointed!

There are probably hundreds of reviews on clannad and clannad:afterstory already. Story: 10
Normally, I hate a story that just revolved around school life because the events that happen are repetitive. Clearly, Clannad is an exception. Despite the plot revolving around normal stuff that happens in school and in the community, the story is somehow very touching. Not only that, the audience can get to know the backstories of pretty much every character in this anime. Some may call these backstories fillers, but I would like to think that they are important in both bringing emotions to the story as well as portraying all the characters. However, the most innovative part of this anime is the story/myth of "the girl who lives in a lonely world" that runs parallel to Tomoya and Nagisa's story. This story reflects Tomoya and Nagisa's states of mind at different stages of their relationship, and contribute nicely to the story (not mentioning the miracle in the end).

Sound: 9

The intro song for both clannad and clannad:afterstory is just amazing. They bring emotions and lift my hearts up. The excerpt songs during some especially dramatic scenes are again, amazing. I watched the dub version, which most people dislike. However, I found that the voice actors did a good job, as the voice of each character is realistic.


Character: 10

This is perhaps the most definte 10 I've ever given. The characters portrayed in this anime is so realistic that the audiences feel like the events that happened in anime happened to themselves. Clannad: After Story: Wishes Come True
I am usually a little skeptical when it comes to these sort of series. Usually in my experience, when something is bragged up to being great, it turns out to be a major disappointment. However, all I can say is WOW! I was BLOWN AWAY! I have to admit that Clannad: After Story was one of the biggest emotional roller coasters of a series I've ever seen, and that's saying something considering how great I found similar series like Angel Beats! and ef-a tale of memories (and melodies) to be. This series was painful to watch and I don't meanin a bad way. Unfortunately, if you went into this series expecting everything to be the same as the original Clannad series, you'd be dead wrong. This series sways much more toward the drama and tragedy aspects than the comedy. This series really plays at your emotions and I have to admit, the latter 2/3 of the series was difficult to sit through on the emotional level. I can't count on one hand how many times I was brought to tears during this stretch. I really enjoy anime series that make me feel and think. This series did both and the nice thing about it is it really gets you to think about your own life and the relationships you form, whether it be with family, friends, your lover, or your child.


The series essentially picks up where Clannad left off...which worked fine for me because I had some criticisms about how open-ended the original series left off. I would highly recommend watching the first series before watching this since I felt the character building in the first series set After Story up rather well. On top of that, it might be easier to pick up on the junk doll and girl story. 


The strength of this series goes back to the characters. The characters are brilliantly written and unlike the first season, I found the story did a better job of narrowing down the roles of the characters. It wasn't the case early on since the first 9 or 10 episodes of the series focused around the Theater Club and some of the hi-jinx involved. However, around episode 9 or 10 is when the ball really got rolling and focused more on the lead characters, Tomoya and Nagisa. To avoid major spoilers, this is where the series took a major U-turn into the drama, romance, and tragedy. Nevertheless, I have to say the next 14 episodes would be some of the most heartwrenching moments I've ever experienced watching an anime.


Another strong point of this series also goes back to the first season as well. The animation and music for this series set a mood that is unmatched. I have to give props to Jun Maeda yet again because the score to this series was God damn brilliant! From OP, to BGM, to insert songs, to ED, the guy played his cards perfectly. Yet again, Lia performed the OP and ED to this series as well as some of the insert songs...and my God is she a perfect performer for this series. Toki o Kizamu Uta, the series OP is one of the most breathtaking songs I've ever heard in an anime. The music as well as the animation was downright fantastic and it had me looking forward to every episode. From an overall production standpoint, I can't help but call Clannad: After Story "a masterpiece in animation."


However, while I did give this series a 10, I'll admit that this series did have some notable flaws. I will admit the first 1/3 of this series didn't get off to the best of starts. For the most part, it felt like filler between the first series and the latter 2/3 of After Story. It wasn't "bad" per se, but seemed awkwardly placed. However, that wouldn't be the first occasion of "awkward placement" in terms of episodes. I have to admit that episode 23 might have been the most worthless episode I've ever seen to a series and considering it's placement, it really shouldn't have been there in the first place. It would've worked fine as a post-Clannad OVA or even a post-After Story OVA...but the second to last episode? It had no business being there.


Oddly enough, this series ended with a recap episode. Usually by my book, this is a major flaw. I am not a big fan of recap episodes in anime and I usually find them to be unnecessary padding. However, I found this to be one of the most brilliantly written recap episodes I've ever seen and it actually cleared up some confusion I had about events in the few episodes leading up to it. I have to admit, the series takes some pretty odd turns toward the end and I found them a little hard to follow. However, the recap episode cleaned everything up perfectly. I never thought I'd say this...but the recap episode saved this series for me and ended the series on the highest of notes.


Overall, there have only been a handful of series in my life that I can say I was "touched" by and this was one of them. I love a series that not only tells a brilliant story, but also makes you think about your own life. This is really a great series to watch if you're in your last year of high school or first year of college because of how heavy-handed it is with it's real-life themes. While yes, I'm aware there are supernatural elements to this series, the message it sends across is easily connected to life events. If you go into this series expecting more or less the same as Clannad, you'll be in for a major surprise for the latter 2/3 of the series, although it will be more or less the same for the first 1/3. Again, I'd highly recommend watching the first season before this one. I don't think it's COMPLETELY necessary but I believe the first season builds some pretty good bonds between the characters and would make you appreciate them that much more in After Story. I will come out and say this was one of the best series I have ever watched and even with it's moments of awkward episode placement, it's one of the most brilliantly written animes I've ever watched. I give it my highest recommendation to anyone, but make sure to go into it with the right mindset or else it could throw you for a loop. I have no qualms in calling Clannad: After Story an anime masterpiece.

This is something really special. 
No show is perfect and this one certainly isn't,  but when taken with its predecessor for context it is undeniably marvelous. Overall, a beautiful and memorable story with some duds here and there.

Clannad After Story is a direct continuation of the story of its predecessor. What could have been a half-assed cash in on the original actually turns out to be one of the best second seasons of an anime I’ve ever seen. While it does have points that it loses momentum and feels kind of like filler, it tells three very distinct, yet connected stories that really seems to work to its emotional advantage. It divides itself between high school dating, marriage, and adulthood. It really shows a progression that gives it the emotional charm that truly makes the show so successful.
The following review is rifewith spoilers, especially the story section. Anyone planning to watch it, but not wishing to have the whole show ruined by me, please skip the story section. I’ll try to keep any spoilers in the other sections to a bare minimum, but this is a warning from me to you. I don’t need angry people with pitchforks and torches standing outside of my door in the morning. So you have been warned.


Story

The original Clannad focused on not only the romantic plot that seemed to be kind of a side story among many side stories, but also many other character’s backgrounds and stories. Clannad After Story does focus on the romance a lot more, and it is well done. The first part of the series focuses on school life as Tomoya finishes high school and Nagisa gets sick and has to go through the grade again. During this time we see a deep emotional connection between the characters, but we also get some baffling seemingly filler episodes concerning the dorm master lady who is not even a character that anyone really cares about at that point. After her side story, we get another half episode of side story about a rocker who I guess is the Kurt Cobain of Japan or something. I really didn’t care, I wanted more of the romantic plot and the characters I cared about.


So the first part of the series is more of what we have come to expect, except Tomoya and Nagisa are dating. The second part is marriage. This comes not as a surprise to anyone of course, but it is a truly heartfelt part where character emotions come into play and we start to get a deep sense of love for these characters, more so than before. As the plot continues, with the birth of Ushio and the death of Nagisa we are plunged into the sudden depths of total despair with Tomoya. This is the part that really made me laugh and cry right along with him. It was heartfelt, it was intense, it was deeply human. Sure it had it’s comedy moments, but it gave you a sense of drama that is unparalleled by most anime.


The end truly baffled me though, and I’m not going to detract any points because of it, but it just seemed kind of nuts. Nagisa lives, Ushio lives, and everyone lives happily ever after in some sort of weird-ass alternate dimension, symbolic thing. Maybe I’m too stupid to understand, which I have said for quite a few anime with truly weird endings. I mean, I see what it was trying to do, but the ending was kind of out there. It did give me a good feeling, it made me happy, it ended with everything tied up. But the way it ended wasn’t what I was expecting.


Animation

The animation is just as good as it was for Clannad. It’s nothing superb or amazing or breathtaking, but it is good. Characters eyes still come across as strange to me. I don’t know why because anime characters have huge eyes most of the time. That’s a given. Yet for some reason, maybe the size of their eyes or something, the girls on this show have eyes that are odd. They don’t detract from anything and actually bring across emotion very well. I digress though.


Sound

Part of the drama of the show comes across so well thanks to the amazing voice work. Tomoya’s voice actor in particular plays his role to a T and never fails to impress. Emotions are injected into every scene by the voice work. The music doesn’t fail either. It has some good music, both the opening and ending are good. Music during the show is essentially the same as Clannad so don’t expect much else. There is a strange song sung in English that makes less sense than a drunk Sylvester Stallone’s recital of Hamlet.


Characters

I can’t tell you how great the characters of the series are. I just can’t. They are beyond words. The original series I commended for the characters but this second series I commend even further. Character development is so well done  and you can see so many changes in every character from beginning to end. This plays into why the emotional scenes work, the characters are so lifelike, so relatable. It makes the show even more fun to watch when you can find characters that you can invest yourself in. Tomoya was especially a great character for me. The tough guy persona but deep inside he’s a friendly, loving, caring person. Nagisa is also a great character. Her development is just as good as Tomoya’s. As Tomoya makes revelations, as the pasts of characters are revealed, it’s amazing how human they seem. I mean, these essentially cartoon characters act even more realistic than the real humans on television. This is the reason the drama works so well and pulls at your heartstrings as much as it does.


To make a long story short, there are no bad characters. There are no unlikeable characters.


Overall

Clannad After Story is an excellent addition to the series and actually exceeds the original in many aspects. When you get further through the series, maybe halfway through, you see a completely different Clannad that turns out to be even more deeply moving, charming, and likeable than the original. Ask me what I would give this anime halfway through and I would probably answer a 7. It didn’t add a lot to the overall formula. But it changes. The series taken as a whole is phenomenal as far as romance/drama’s go. This particular season is a huge part of that. It’s a great ending to the series.


It’s the best drama anime I’ve ever seen.

First of all, I would like to say Clannad is definitely on of the most beautiful anime I've seen for the past 9 years I started watching anime. It's story is so fabulous(woah, I've never used that word, haha) that it can make you smile, laugh, frown, cry, and ask for more. It has this somewhat complex charm that appeals to its viewers and it stays true to its promises. 
The art is well-done. I mean, it's well detailed and amazing. Animation is nicely done and some moments are such eye candy. Seeing as how it's a slice of life anime, the art is expectedto seem realistic and it is. The CGI used on some character(s) are also superb. However, it's an anime so we can't expect it to be somewhere near looking like a live-action.


As for the sound, it fits perfectly to the events of the show. I mean, when the atmosphere is sad, the music helps out the mood. Same goes for being happy. It's not like in some where the mood is sad and then the music is happy, haha. It's music is just right. A nice blend of sad and happy music forming with sad and happy events that makes this one spectacular anime. 


Characters are very unique and also give importance to the story. What I'm saying is for example: Cinderella could've been anyone, but in Clannad, the main character gives out importance. In other words, a story like Cinderella could've happened to anyone, but a story like Clannad can only happen to its unique characters. Namely Nagisa, the heroine of the story, whose personality and character traits make her important to the story. Likewise the message I'm trying to give is that the story of Cinderella could've happened to Snow White or Sleeping Beauty, but the story of Clannad would hardly happen to characters from another anime.


Finally, we go for how we enjoy this anime. I've seen many anime from my experiences and I've enjoyed most of them. Clannad is one of those most. With a performance that is phenomenal, you could watch it several times again and again because of the ways it makes you laugh and cry. Overall, Clannad is definately one of the best anime out there...in my opinion, that is. And I do know most of you could agree on that.

You know how some anime tend to make you smile? To make you laugh, or perhaps  make you cry instead? If an anime is well-writen and executed, it will at least induce a certain feeling. In another review I said that an anime made my heart cry. Clannad - After Story did not only that. It made it cry, commit suicide about 15 times, then tore itself up into pieces and glued itself back together. Needless to say, it was a rather painful experience, but I'm glad I sat through it till the end.
After Story follows up on the first season of Clannad, butin overall, both seasons are completely different experiences. It involves two of the main characters from the first season, Tomoya and Nagisa, and their evergrowing relationship. At first you may think that the concept itself isn't very unique. But the way their relationship progresses is unlike any other regular anime, as your average high school anime tends to stop at the end of high school. After Story not only surpasses that, it brings us a well-written story of what happened to the two after their debut in the first season. 


The first season helped develop the overall story, shape the characters and their relationships and set the mood, and the second season uses this to its fullest potential by delivering a heartwarming and at the same time a heartbreaking experience, with its happy and sad moments. And when I say sad, I mean really sad, and this is accomplished by the overall character development. Thanks to the base the first season provided, you really feel with the people in After Story far more than you would in any other anime. But of course by getting along with the characters like that, the hardships they face have a much bigger impact than they normally would, and it is understandable if you have to take a (small) break from the anime when you can't bear it anymore. It can really be that sad.


Now, this anime isn't a full-blown Slice of Life like it might sound. It really leans toward the super-natural phenomena the city our main characters live in experiences. In the first season, I didn't care so much about that, and focused more on the main character progression and such. But in the end, it played a rather important role in After Story, and without it, we would not have seen the hardships our couple go through in the anime, and teach them (and us) the lessons they've learned during that time. As long as something like this, the super-natural being an important part in an anime like this one, is done right, it really complements the overall feel and story of it, giving it an even more complete shape than it already had.


The art is really great, with the characters looking either cool or quite cute. The overall color contrasts and lighting are amazingly executed, and it will always create the proper atmosphere for each scene. When a sad scene commences, the ambience, lighting, colors, even the art style will slightly change to maximize the experience we're seeing on screen. Often this will get to you in a way that you didn't expect, and if you notice the sides of your eyes getting a bit watery, it means it has done its job nicely.


The music... Oh god, the music. There are songs in this anime that will get to you. Not just during the anime, but after you've watched the entire thing, whenever you hear one of the songs played in the show, and especially one in particular, you might have to cover your ears to prevent the memories from seeping in. The music is very well written, and really add to the overall atmosphere this anime has. I wouldn't say it's the best music I've ever heard, but I certainly wouldn't have wanted anything else than what it's got today. They did an amazing job composing the music so that it fits with the proper scenes, and once again will add to the sadness you'll be experiencing when it happens.


As you may have noticed from my writing, do not watch Clannad and After Story if you have a weak heart, or overall prefer more happy and carefree anime like Lucky Star and Nichijou, and normally I would stick to those anime as well. But let me tell you this. Seldom has an anime moved me the way Clannad did, and I'm really glad I mustered up the courage to sit through it all. In the end, it left me with a satisfied feeling, with pretty much all the questions answered and all the loose ends tied. If you're a fan of anime in general, you should definitely watch this masterpiece. It might rip your heart apart, but it will probably feel like the best thing that has ever happened to you.

Animation:
The first thing you have to talk about in an anime is the animation! Clannad has never been something to write home to about, but I was pleased to see After Story had some much-needed improvement. Movements were more fluid, facial expressions are TOP NOTCH and really enhance the quality of the scenes, and the backgrounds looked great. I assume the art style was just to keep it in-line with the visual novel and as a result, we have Nagisa's eyes. (UPDATE: In 1080p it SHINES with clear, crisp animation. However, in darker scenes the animation gets cloudy and degrades in quality).
Sound:
The opening is regardedas being one of the best in all of anime fandom. I completely agree and as the series progresses the opening gets better, due to events in the show. The ending is ok; not exactly as good as Secret Base from AnoHana or the ending from the first series, but still decent. The shows actual music is hit or miss. It's a very visual novel-y, which I tend not to like. Fate/Stay Night (also a visual novel originally) had a superior score, redone by Kenji Kawaii. There is one thing that must be said though. In all the moments it has to the music REALLY pulls through and makes the scene. By the time you finish episode 16, you'll understand what I mean.


The show's dub is mediocre. I wound up watching it subbed and I'm glad I did. Tomoya's voice actor is phenomenal. Every emotion is brought to life as he speaks and it's incredibly convincing. The rest of the cast is also quite good. Akio is melo-dramatic and theatrical. Sanae is always amusing in her comedic crying fits over bread. Fuko is as childish as ever. 


Characters:

The biggest problem with an anime based on a visual novel is that the main character is usually shovelware. This DEFINITELY was NOT the case with Clannad After Story. In fact, Tomoya was one of the most excellent leading characters I have ever seen. All his expressions, reactions, and dialogue is very believable and contains great depth. Granted he isn't as scripted as Lelouch from Code Geass, but this allows the viewer to fill into his role. Thus experiencing the emotion in a more first-hand kind of way. I was never really a fan of Nagisa. Her animation really lets the character down, but in the later parts of After Story, she really comes into her own. Akio is a refreshing character. Managing to be both serious and comedic in equal proportions. The rest of the harem isn't really shown much, but that's understandable considering the flow of the story this time around.


Story:


Clannad After Story is a medley of emotions. You'll laugh, shed tears of sadness and tears of joy. You'll feel yourself in the story. The first part of Clannad After Story, which I really enjoyed was when we get to see into Misae's (the dorm mother's) past. That story could EASILY hold its own anime. Very romantic and very fun. The ending was a tad bit stupid though, but it was the predictable ending. The arc about delinquents and gangs was tedious, but it's worth watching to reach the true story of Clannad. Tomoya's life with his family. The ending wasn't what I had hoped for, although most viewers will be satisfied with it (depending on your preferences of course). At the very least it won't leave you bitter. The ending is very visual novel-ish. You "unlock" the true route when you collect enough of an item. Despite that, it was a decent ending and the rest of the show's story is phenomenal.

As I write this review, I sit beside a bucket full of the manly tears that I shed.
Clannad, Clannad: After Story, what an emotional rollercoaster it has been. You made me laugh like a fool, then cry my heart out, all in the blink of an eye.
I really wish the writer(s) got a Booker for the story. Everything from the start to the end was beautifully planned out. Each and every episode felt relevant, adding more quality to the characters and plot.
Individually, Clannad was good; it depicts the life of a high school delinquent, till he meets the love of his life. Typical high schoolplot, with a lot of take on humour (so much that my roommate probably thinks I need professional 'help'), with a few tear jerking moments. Each episode serves a meaning. In fact, Clannad is not as emotional as After Story, but it builds up the story. The characters literally have life injected into them; you will come to not only fall in love with the characters, but project yourself into a few of them. This part might appear over hyped, but it is rightly so, especially because of what's about to come; it was downright necessary.


After Story, where do I start. The first half of the series continued on from Clannad, and depicts the remainder of their highschool lives. Once again, lots of humour, meaningful episodes and nostalgic reminders of school life (I graduated quite a while back, so it does serve as stigma to hidden memories).


Come the second half. I seriously question the legitimacy of my manhood. I cried like I had not in years. Each of the issues that were appearing throughout the series will eventually be answered with the most heart wrenching of conclusions. If you had had a good laugh till now, cherish it; you will be dropped in a well of despair.


But fear not, as the ending will pick you up, and shine a ray of hope. It does end on a happy note, which I felt was extremely necessary, given all the tears that I had shed. The story is gripping, with the viewer becoming more curious everyday as to the fate of the characters (I binge watched half of After Story in a day, especially when it reached its climax)


And FYI, I had read a few of the spoilers beforehand, to prepare myself emotionally, but it still managed to drain the fluids from my body.


Will I give it a rewatch? I fear not, as I am not emotionally prepared to face these turmoils again. A must watch, definitely.






Now I need to go watch some shounen/seinen to man myself up again.

that Bob Marley movie was fucking awesome, now, on to the Clannad after story review...
"After story" is an adaptation from the original Visual Novel by KEY and the sequel to Clannad, and continues the story of Nagisa and Tomoya okazaki`s relationship with each other and those around them while living in the city that they love so much. 
I will admit something before I go any further. I went into this anime not wanting to like it, as I was “such a big fan” of the orginal manipulating one dimensional turd known as clannad that Ithought I would be in for another big plate of horse shit with this sequel, but as it turned out I would have to get my doctor ordered daily supply of horse shit somewhere else because Clannard after story was a surprisingly good ride proving that you can teach an old dog new tricks, except for my dog sparky, the only new trick he seems to have learned is how to decompose on my couch.


Anyway most people have probably already seen this series before but for those who haven't I will keep spoilers to a minimum. So anyway in its simplest terms “After Story” is about people, relationships and of course growing up, and it does this in a very realistic, enjoyable and surprisingly insightful way without feeling forced. For the most part it felt genuine and sincere which is very rare in anime these days, with very few moments feeling contrived or too cliché. In fact this is one of the few anime`s that one could actually believe that the characters are real people and act as real people would in their situations, which was a big fucking surprise to me given that this is a sequel to Clannad, where people act like, well, fucking one dimensional video game characters.      


“After story” basically builds upon Nagisa and Tomoya`s relationship, which starts with them just going out with each other and eventually growing into much bigger things and of course as these things happen and they get older all the challenges that they have to face along with all the amazing things that happen to them. Anyway Clannad After Story excels where Clannad failed miserably, namely in making you care and feel for the characters and in getting you emotionally involved,  which is basically what this anime is really about, getting the audience emotionally invested in the lives of these fictional characters more so than telling a story, which is fine, I enjoyed it a lot and it never felt boring or slow, which is is a great accomplishment given that this is very much a slice of live anime, proving once again that big fight scenes and special effects are no substitute for a good story and believable characters. I suppose you could say the story of “After Story” is without sounding too cliché, about life, and the challenges that all of us most one day face while we're alive. And for the most part After Story does this very well in a mature and realistic manner, even touching on subjects that many animes wouldn't dare touch such as child birth, being a parent, loneliness and loss. 

And this is where this anime really shines with its realism and true life grittiness, sure it still has some of the cutesy elements left over from clannad but there used sparingly and appropriately and don't do the show much harm.  Really as far as story or plot goes there really isn't any and that fine because there doesn't need be because this is a story about life, belonging and growing up. Going into too much depth about this stuff exactly would just spoil things for others how haven't seen it yet which I don't like too do to people, unless their black... shit I mean, oh on, crap how do I delete thi....  


As far as sound goes in this series I was very impressed, there are some good pieces of music here that really help to set the mood and make you feel what's going on even more, however I have one complaint and that's that for the first ¾ of the show any-time the anime wants us to feel very emotional they play the same piece of music again and again. It got to the point where I was rolling my eyes every-time it stared thinking “oh God not again, I GET IT! IM SUPPOSED TO FEEL SAD, THANK YOU!   


One of the smartest changes “After Story” made was keeping most of the other characters from Clannad out of this series or at least subdued, the reason for this is because they just wouldn't work in this new realistic, gritty setting. There come's a time in our lives where we see something that can just change our lives, whether we change our personality to changing the way we see life. And it can be from something as great as an original story to something that had been used many times but only changed something that can hit you right in the core. This is what I felt like when I saw Clannad: After Story
Story is a continuation of the 1st season of Clannad, where it ends Tomoya and Nagisa finally being a couple. And it literally starts right there. Overall this is not only of one of my favorite anime of all time, but also one of the greatest thing I've seen in my life

Honestly you can just skip this review if you want to. I know there are tons of reviews of Clannad After Story and a 10/10 rating is nothing new for one of the highest rated shows on MAL, but, after watching Clannad After Story for the third time, I just felt like I needed to do this. As the sixth anime I watched after really getting into anime a little over a year ago and my favorite anime for a long time, Clannad After Story is very special to me and something I hardlygo a week or two without thinking about at least once.


The best way I can think to describe this show in a few words would be “traumatic and life-changing.” Clannad After Story is renowned as one of the saddest anime created so far by many people, and is, to date, the only thing I have watched of any medium (anime or not) since I was a little kid watching “The Tigger Movie” that has ever made me cry. Not only that, but it has succeeded at doing so all three times that I have watched it.


What Clannad After Story is famous for is being one of the few romance anime to go beyond where most romantic tales end. The first season of Clannad ends with Tomoya confessing to Nagisa and the two of them becoming a couple. This is where most romance stories end, but Clannad goes beyond that and, while it is mostly the same as the first season for the first 8 episodes, it soon moves on and explores further into the lives of our protagonists and the trials and tribulations that come with life, romance, and family.


While this show does have a good amount of comedy, it separates it very well from the heartwarming and heartbreaking drama that Clannad After Story is truly known for. The drama of the first season does not even compare to the amount of emotions that this show conveys perfectly to the viewer.



The story of Clannad After Story continues the high school lives of Okazaki Tomoya, Furukawa Nagisa, and everyone else that they met and became friends with in the first season. For the first eight episodes, it focuses on several short 2-3 episode arcs about three of the minor characters who did not receive arcs in the first season. These are nice in their own way (and the last one about Yukine has one of my favorite endings of any of the arcs in Clannad minus the longer After Story arc), but the real story, and where it begins to become something unique in anime, begins in Episode 9.


Then the show quickly turns a 180 from being a shounen romance about a high school boy helping his friends solve their problems and helping Nagisa make friends, to a seinen romance about a “kid trying to act like an adult” (to paraphrase Yoshino Yusuke) who is trying to figure out where his life is going as his relationship with his girlfriend develops.


Speaking of which, the amount of character development that Tomoya goes through during these 22 episodes is phenomenal. I believe he is the most developed anime character I have ever seen and rightfully earns a spot high on my favorite characters list. At the beginning of the first season of Clannad, Tomoya was just a delinquent with a couple friends who hated his father and hated the town he lived in. After meeting Nagisa and changing her life while changing his own in the process, he eventually ended up where he is at the beginning of After Story. But even with all of that development, Tomoya develops much, much further during After Story (specifically after Episode 16).


Nagisa, who was hardly more important than the other leading females in the first season, is now in the spotlight along with Tomoya. As tough as Tomoya has it during this season, life is much harder on Nagisa. She keeps getting sick and missing school, but she still manages to keep their relationship strong and helps Tomoya succeed as he struggles to get his life started. The After Story arc (basically Episode 9 to the end) focuses on Nagisa, and she really makes this show one of the best there is.


Akio and Sanae Furukawa also step up their roles during this season. Personally I think Akio is possibly the best anime father there is and one of the best parents I’ve ever seen in general. The only thing against him is that taking pictures of your daughter at work disguised as a rapper is more than a little weird. Akio and Sanae help Tomoya and Nagisa start their lives and, aside from Yoshino, are really the only returning characters from the first season who have larger roles in the second season as everyone else goes their separate ways with only occasional appearances after Episode 9.



Now for the art, which I know is what turns many people away from this show. Personally I love the character designs in Clannad, but I know many people dislike the large “moe” eyes that are a standard in Kyoto Animation shows.


Aside from the character designs, the backgrounds and scenery of the small town Hikarizaka that the characters live in looks amazing to me. It’s a big step up one year after the first season. The Hidden World also looks stunning with a combination of 3D for the mechanical doll and machinery and 2D for everything else.


With the drama and emotional scenes also comes amazing artwork. Often different colors are used for these scenes and the lighting effects work really well to compliment this. The elements of rain and snow are commonly used to intensify the emotion of the scenes. Whether it’s fighting for something with everything you’ve got or the extreme feelings of loneliness and hopelessness, the scenery in Clannad After Story compliments everything spectacularly.


The soundtrack in Clannad (as with most Kyoto Animation and/or Key visual novel anime) is one of the best there is. Whether it’s the childish yet emotional “Big Family Dango” theme song or the dramatic “Town, Flow of Time, People,” the soundtrack is nearly flawless with almost every single song (whether lighthearted or emotional) standing out. The only song I dislike, called “Ana,” is one that plays during Episode 20 which butchers the English language so badly that I have no idea what they are even trying to say. It kind of ruins the mood of one part of that episode, but since it is only played once, really does not hinder the show’s overall soundtrack very much.


Other than that, the soundtrack doesn’t miss a beat. The Japanese voice actors are also very good (I won’t say anything about choosing English or Japanese because if you’ve already watched one season, then changing would be difficult), but I just really love the emotions that characters (especially Tomoya, have I mentioned how much I love Tomoya yet?) show. Everyone sounds the part perfectly, and even Sunohara gets some good emotional moments.



Enjoyment and Overall – 10/10


I highly recommend to anyone who has watched the first season of Clannad to watch Clannad After Story. Similar shows would be Ef: a Tale of Memories, AnoHana, and Chuunibyou, though none of those are quite as emotional as Clannad After Story.


But then again, I don’t believe there is any show, movie, or anything else that currently exists that is as emotional as Clannad After Story. It is a masterpiece which goes where most romance stories do not dare go. It has amazing characters with tons of development, an amazing soundtrack, good art as long as the big beautiful eyes do not bother you, and it ties everything together with its amazingly crafted unique story. Clannad After Story will forever be one of my favorite anime and the anime I feel the most nostalgia for. And I truly believe that it is this emotional appeal that makes Clannad AS so loved by many fans and allows the critics to overlook its cliche storyline. Art (8/10) \n
I had no huge problems with the art other than the fact that all the girls seemed to look alike (aside from their hair color). it bugged me -- a little. But not much. \n\n

fantastic soundtrack. i downloaded all of them. the serene/mellow tracks are definitely my favorite. It was a shame that the story focuses purely on Tomoya and Nagisa (although I did prefer it since the story was given a better focus) becase it sacrificed the huge number of character cast that Clannad boasted before. \n\n
Enjoyment (10/10) \n\n
Overall (8.3/10) \n
 while I didn’t bawl at any point in the series, I did have moments where I had goosebumps and when I just felt a part of my heart shatter looking at their tears (helloooooo episode 18 -- an episode I've watched countless, countless of times. It's my favorite episode by miles and miles. It’s one of the major reasons why I think this anime is gold). It has an amazing emotional component that easily out does many, many of the same animes in its genre. I could definitely hail Clannad AS as one of the greatest romantic animes of its time, and although the Clannad series on the whole (including original Clannad) has its bumps and flaws, I’m glad I finished it up until the very end.

[This review probably contains spoilers, probably is too lengthy, probably is too personal and probably goes off on a tangent you weren't interested in. ]
"It's OK now. You did well. Now it's your turn to cry." -- Akio to Sanae
"It looks like I finished things without even realizing it." -- Tomoya's father
Clannad Afterstory is universally recognized as a show that can and will make many (most) viewers tear up, or even start bawling. 
While many people are touched, or even moved, by the tragedy and heartbreak, a fair portion of reviewers see a relatively average romantic-comedy-slice-of-life show being elevated by blatantly drawing on viewers tearducts, making viewers forget that they watched 40 episodes of , in some people's opinions, mediocrity to get to this point. 


I'd like to argue that Clannad Afterstory has an underlying theme which is far more important than wet eyeballs and drama: what it truly means to be a parent, and to forgive a parent.


It's common knowledge that parents are generally absent from anime. Between boarding schools, orphans, and parents with bizarre work schedules, the only time we typically see parents is as a form of comic relief.   This could be due to the younger audience, or it could just be because parents are hard characters to get right. 


Clannad gets parents right. They are human beings, not disciplinary robots who dispense useless platitudes, and they have numerous, numerous faults. At the same time, they aren't these appalling monsters who revile their children and regret ever having them (another anime trope...). They suffer, they cry, they falter, but despite flaws they care about their children and go to great lengths to support them. This is how most parents exist in the real world. Instead of ignoring the parent-child relationship, Clannad Afterstory explores it in depth and uses family as the strength necessary for the characters to persevere through tragedy. 


With the faults and strengths of the parents naturally comes the concept of forgiveness. There are many things in Clannad that are forgiven. In other anime, Tomoya might continue hating his father to the end. Akio and Sanae may never forgive Nagisa for halting their dreams. Akio, Sanae, and Ushio might always view Tomoya as the deadbeat who walked out on his child. And Tomoya might never forgive himself. 


Clannad does forgive these characters, and in doing so tries to tell you to do so as well. In the end, their lives are easier and more complete because they are able to forgive. 


Clannad Afterstory isn't just about crying at loss. The two scenes that touched me the most aren't the two most tragic, but rather the two I quoted at the start. Those scenes helped remind me the sacrifices my mother made, and to forgive my mother for some of the things she has done. 


And if I have to watch 40 episodes of melancholic slice-of-life to remember that, despite her faults, my mother's love is what truly matters, well it's damn well worth it.

Slice of Life and Drama animes are ones I don't generally like. I'm more of the action, comedy with a hint of romance anime lover, but Clannad: After Story changed that for me! (I recommend watching Clannad before watching this anime...)  Clannad: After Story will definitely become one of your favorite animes because it certainly became one of mine. For starters, I'd just like to say that I usually NEVER cry while watching a movie, anime, book or show of any sort. Clannad: After Story was different though, it did in fact make me tear up, especially towards episode 18 and up. So here'show I scored each element of the anime:


Story: 10

Art: 9

Sound: 9

Character: 10

Enjoyment: 10 

Overall: 10


Now I shall go ahead and give you the reasons as to why these areas were scored the way they were! :) I tried not to put any spoilers in this review, but I still would read with caution because hints of the upcoming event are given...


Story: 10

This is definitely the most important part of an anime for me. If the story isn't good, the whole thing kinda fails, same goes with the characters. The story does run a bit slow at times, but to be fair, it is a 'slice of life' type anime and life doesn't always go all over the place in full speed. The story picks right up from Clannad, which makes me very happy because we get to see the main characters gradually grow more mature and eventually get married and so on... The story also has many situations and areas where everyone can relate to, giving it a strong connection with the viewers. The father-son (Tomoya and his father) and father-daughter (Tomoya and his daughter) relationship was a big point in the story. The way they showed another side of Tomoya's father through flashbacks and such, showed a new side to the man that many might have thought mean, cold and selfish during Clannad. This made me really happy and made the anime more realistic, showing that a person's heart isn't fully rock solid. WARNING: Clannad: After Story plays with your emotions, causing you to feel very sad and sympathetic or empathetic! 


Art: 9

I'm not too prickly about my art preference, but I ended up scoring Clannad: After Story an 9 because I generally like more realistic looking characters... I guess? Maybe characters without such big eyes...but, the backgrounds were beautiful, I especially loved the parts where it goes to a different world where the girl lives all alone with the light orbs. :)


Sound: 9

Dango, dango, dango, dango.... that song makes me smile every time I here it  now!Oh, Nagisa! I really liked how a more mellow song was chosen for the opening to kind of set the mood, but then the closing song is more upbeat, which uplifts my spirited after a heavily heart tearing episode. The sound tracks were great! 


Character: 10

Like I said in my little Story scoring blurb, the characters are important! Clannad: After Story did not fail me on that! The characters were all pretty much developed because of Clannad, but they managed to develop them EVEN MORE! Again, like I had said on my Story scoring paragraph, Tomoyo's father was more explored and the reasons for the way he was acting are revealed, causing you to feel different emotions toward him than of those you felt during Clannad. Nagisa is still her stubborn, lovable self. Her mom is still the supportive woman she is, and Nagisa's father, likewise, is still as comedic and awesome as usual...Tomoya on the other hand...reacts the way many human beings might after facing a huge set back in his life, causing him to feel very depressed and...lonely...Anywho! You'll love the characters!The anime gets you to become attached to these characters, making it EVEN MORE sad and hurtful to the heart when something goes wrong for them...and on the other hand, when something amazingly happy happens to them, you'll feel that warmth in your heart as well!


Enjoyment: 10

I loved, loved, loved every second of this anime! I cried, I smiled, I laughed, I was given many different facial expressions throughout this anime! I enjoyed it very much! Episodes 18 and up were the ones I liked the most! 


Overall: 10

It's just an all around great anime! I really recommend people to watch Clannad: After Story!

Clannad: The After Story is an absolute masterpiece. 
So, why do I consider this one of the most beautiful stories not just in anime, but in the visual medium of entertainment in general?  Well firstly, this is absolutely the most beautiful show that I have ever seen.  The choreography and cinematography work in tandem with the setting and dialogue to elevate this show past anything I have ever seen before.  From the longer shots of our main protagonists walking through the town or having a stunning and emotional moment the writers know what to focus on visually.  Couple that with themost stunningly beautiful soundtrack to ever be created and you get an anime that takes “showing the story” to a whole new level.


Secondly, the characters are absolutely some of the most memorable and identifiable characters to ever be brought to film.  Okazaki is the embodiment of a young adult who is attempting to grow and find his place in life.  Nagisa is an absolute beauty, and her timid but extremely caring personality that drives most of the show is very well done.  The side cast of characters is brought back from the original Clannad, but in the After story, most of the show focuses on the newly created family bonds between Okazaki and Nagisa.  It is during these interactions that the writers create a lot of heavy emotion because the characters are so identifiable and realistic, and the situations that they are put in are also very identifiable.  These characters and their interactions are so well done and subtly beautiful that it builds the emotions throughout the show and creates massive amounts of heartbreak when the characters have to deal with the changes in their lives.  Finally, when it comes to characters, Ushio may just be the single best portrayal of a young child any show has ever created.  Her dialogue and her interactions with her family are so beautiful, funny, and emotionally tear-jerking that you can tell a massive amount of thought went into the careful construct of her character.


Finally, the overall theme of the show is about the struggles of adulthood, but also about how quickly things can change and be taken away.  The beginning half of the show is fantastic as we see arcs that carried over from the original Clannad conclude but the back half depicting the changes and extreme hardships that the characters must deal with was without a doubt one of the most beautiful and heartbreaking stories to ever be brought to the visual realm of entertainment (you have been warned).  These extreme hardships that last throughout the back half of the show had me in tears just about every few episodes, and as the emotion built to its very emotional and satisfying conclusion, it left me unable to stop reflecting on what I had just witnessed for nearly a month.  It has been over a year since I watched this show, and I still remember every single bit of beautiful and stunning screen time this show created.  


The combination of subtle beauty, extremely identifiable characters, relatable emotional struggles, and heartbreaking emotional sequences place this show in a league of its own.  Clannad: The After Story is simply a must watch for any anime fan.

It gives at least a droplet realism to totally unrealistic situation where “useless outcast” gets surrounded by three thousand cute girls. At least there are two males here. And… that's it about school characters praise.


First half follows format of prequel where two-three episodes comprise an arc that regales us some incredibly genuine, kind, naive, breathtaking, heart-soothing story about happiness and sadness, values of love, friendship, family, dedication and diligence. I admit, they are good. But nothing more. As always,  Japanese are painting life problems in a *ideal* world which immediately renders them worthless in all aspects but one: aesthetic pleasure. But I do (not) complain. It’s standart in anime. Just, specifically in Clannad After Story, I can’t help but berate some ark moments: the ‘evil’ soccer team (like, come on, contrast in decency between Tomoya group and soccer team was so immense that it don’t know how else to name other than idiotic; the only thing missing was evil laughter ‘MU HAH HA’ and we would have got typical japanese villain), gangs wars (‘noble bandits’, yeah, totally realistic). But, as I said, the stories *are* entrancing. They leave you with aftertaste of joy, delight and, more often, gentle sadness. If you a romance lover, that is.


In any case, life goes on and after ten or so episodes Tomoya graduates school and becomes fully fledged grownup. And that’s where Clannad After Story really begins and elevates above the throngs of mediocre animes, rightfully taking the title of second best slice of life series.


=====================================

It’s hard for me to pinpoint the greatness of this part, as objectively speaking, we are still presented with same ideal kind word where each problem is resolved by naive virtue known to any six year old. But that’s the point, isn’t it? Right way is simple and yet few can follow it. And so is Tomoya, who now enters adult life devoid of strong purpose and lacking experience. And thus begins his long journey of transformation from listless no one to earnest member of society. Yet life is known to be a bitch so this journey is filled tragedies and obstacles…


And this is probably what you’ve been advertised of, am I right? “The legendary tragedy Clannad After Story”. Well, if you haven’t, than I say it. Indeed, the struggle of Tomoya’s day to day existence won’t leave unscathed even the most callous cynic. There can’t be a touching story filled solely with happiness. Tomoya’s tale isn’t exception. There would be grieve… but with genuine effort and support of loved ones it’ll turn into candid happiness. 


The tune is old as pyramids yet Clannad portrayal is so sincere, so honest that it goes straight to the heart and keeps grip on it until very end. And, to be honest, it’s still very naive, but at same time it is so *right*. It is so right that you can’t help but look at yourself, wondering “How can I change for the better?”. Yes, it’s one of the few art pieces capable of changing outlook on life. Even if a little, it’s still tremendous feat.


Concerning narrative, we still have same storytelling arc format. But, as there is no school anymore, subjects are shifted towards more realistic daily problems such as work and family. Each event is supplemented with rich Tomoya’s introspective. School friends fades into background which is, in fact, immensely positive change. Few characters I didn’t mention before become prominent: Nagisa’s parents, eccentric and absurdly young looking couple. They fit quite nicely to the story and deserve credit.


=====================================

In general, Clannad wins not with pure plot or writing but with directing and presentation. The drawing style seems mind blowing at first but quite quickly gets pleasant and casual (though shots with multiple faces still look ridiculous). Music matches perfectly to each situation; delicate magical feel of it readies your eyes to spurt a few tears at culmination of the arc. But what moves more than anything is sincere honesty of unfolding life which will surely resonate with your own.


School Days: 5/10

After Story 10/10


Total: 7.5/10 ~ 8

Clannad AS, more than anything, is a story grounded in the humanity of its characters. It contains none of the heartbreaking romance, breathtaking action sequences, or mind-boggling mystery we see so often in the anime, or in general entertainment medium, yet manages to be even more tell a tale even more gripping than any other I’ve seen. Clannad AS is both a complex and simplistic work, and personifies people; we witness people at their happiest, living to protect what only they can protect, and at their lowest, falling into a pit of despair and grief over the loss of loved ones. We see them changeas they meet new people and broaden their horizons, as they become optimistic about the world around them, yet down the road, regretful of these very changes as they bear the pain of loss. We see them gain, lose, re-gain, then lose again, in a cycle of hope and despair.


At the core of Clannad AS is the story of one man, who seems to have been abandoned to a hopeless fate, despising all and despised by all around him. His mother died young, leaving him with his drunken, abusive father who shuns him after an accident that left him crippled. However, his pessimistic, hate-filled view of his surroundings changed when he met Nagisa, the woman who changed every aspect of his outlook and personal life. As he learns the hardship, yet ultimate joy that comes with the burden of protecting the one he loves, life suddenly becomes worth living. Yet it is the loss of his loved ones, his failure and inability to save the people he cared about, that sent him reeling back into his pool of self-fueled hate and grief. And through this black hole of pain, the shining light of hope, the last remainder of his love, was able to be his salvation.


It would seem that, from the premise, Clannad AS is simply a romantic story, a story of a happily married couple spending each day doing what they love. However, the story transforms into something much deeper than that, it explores the confines of what it means to be human. What does it mean to protect? What does it mean to love? Is love worth the pain that comes with loss? The human relationships depicted in the anime are extremely beautiful and touching, but above all they are realistic. Watching Clannad AS made me realize how amazing humans really are, that the strength of familial bonds and friendship can truly overcome any obstacles, whether it be grief, responsibility, or death. Indeed, the lines between fiction and reality blurred as I became absorbed into the realistic and heartfelt storytelling of Clannad AS.


Clannad AS is certainly a very sad anime, and you will see this stressed in many other reviews. However, it’s not simply a tearjerker; the sadness has more depth than simple melodrama. What truly brought tears to my eyes was how touching and beautiful human relationships can be: a father who collects all the fragments of his shattered life to protect his daughter, a daughter who forgives and continues to love a father who abandoned her, a grandfather who sacrifices anything and everything to protect what he loves and believes in. For such a seemingly simplistic anime about the bonds of a few people, Clannad AS has an amazing depth. The magnitude of its depth is shown magnificently through the relationships and unbreakable bonds of family, through both the struggle and the happiness of its characters.
